results.title: Bollywood bound
results.creator_credit: Nisha Pahuja, Karen King-Chigbo and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The world’s largest film industry centre of Bollywood has not only attracted hopeful actors from all over India, but also ethnic Indians born in other countries. This documentary follows four young Indo-Canadians as they travel to Bombay in the hope of landing roles in a Bollywood production. Raised on a diet of Hindi movies in Canada which have played a significant role in the formation of their ethnic identities, they are dismayed to find on their arrival in Bombay that despite their cultural heritage and their deep familiarity with Indian popular culture, they are deemed ‘not Indian enough’. The film blends Bollywood clips with the budding actors’ experiences in Bombay as they attempt to gain entry into the industry and discover the reality behind the fantasy of their beloved movies. In the process it offers an insight into contemporary formations of ethnic identity and the complexity of East-West cultural hybrids in the context of an increasingly globalised popular entertainment industry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nisha Pahuja, Karen King-Chigbo and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Bolivia: the tin mountain
results.creator_credit: Martin Smith, David Elstein and Thames Television
results.brief_description: A moving presentation showing the desperate poverty in the lives of the tin miners of Bolivia. Notes the problems of lack of capital, absentee ownership of the tin mines, market forces and the political system which influence the prices of tin and hence the life style of the miners. Narrated by Jonathan Dimbleby. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Bolgene
results.brief_description: Two young men who have been boyhood friends for years are taking their regular holiday together on a Scandanavian island. However, with approaching adulthood, the sexual tensions in their relationships begin to emerge. This is a serious and beautifully crafted story about adolescence and innocence, and the inevitability of change. By concentrating on the physicality and intimacy of the two male bodies in space, Mosvold creates a haunting, resonating work.

results.title: BOLD = Blind outdoor leisure development
results.brief_description: At Aspen, in the Rocky Mountains, U.S.A., an organisation called Blind Outdoor Leisure Development enables blind people to participate in many sports. With experienced guides, 500 blind people are involved in all kinds of sports, including skiing, ice-skating, horseriding, fishing, mountain climbing, rafting in the Colorado rapids, and experiencing wildlife. Narrated by John Denver. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: BoJack Horseman
results.brief_description: Meet the most beloved sitcom horse of the 90s - 20 years later. BoJack Horseman was the star of the hit TV show “Horsin’ Around,” but today he’s washed up, living in Hollywood, complaining about everything, and wearing colorful sweaters.

constellations_other.name: City of animals (Hollow Knight - Production Design)
constellations_other.description: The adorable bugs that occupy Hallownest in the game Hollow Knight aren't the first anthropomorphised critters in film.

results.title: Boiling point = 3-4x jagutsu
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Kitano, Masayuki Mori, Takio Yoshida, Hisao Nabeshima and Bandai, Shockiku-Fuji, Institute of the Contemporary Arts
results.brief_description: Masahiko (Masahiko Ono) is a young gas station attendant whose life revolves around work and baseball. Though usually lazy and inert, Masahiko creates havoc when he punches a rude customer who turns out to be a highly violent gangster. With the gangsters seeking revenge, Masahiko sets out with his best friend to buy a gun in Okinawa. There they meet up with a violent thug (Takeshi Kitano) who takes them on an increasingly absurd road trip in which moral, sexual and criminal codes all become increasingly mixed up. “Beat” Takeshi’s second feature continues his highly idiosyncratic exploration of the gangster film in which operatic moments of violence are contrasted by elegant and largely wordless scenes of contemplation and respite. Kitano’s movies are uniquely personal examinations of masculinity. His own performance in “Boiling Point” as the bisexual misogynist gangster is by turns highly comical and highly confronting. In this ambivalent movie the rituals and cliches of the gangster and yakuza film are both celebrated and the rigorously undermined. The aimless young characters who come into contact with the underworld of crime soon realise that beneath the posturing and display of excess and wealth, there is finally only the shattering certainty of death. It is sometimes said that film noir owes a great debt to existentialism: it may be that Kitano is one of its greatest philosophers.

results.title: Boiler house practice
results.creator_credit: George Wynn and C W S Film Unit
results.brief_description: This film was made to encourage economy in the use of fuel through efficient boiler house practice. Points mentioned include: correct tools, methods of hand-firing, control of air-flow, care of mechanical stokers, regular cleaning of heating surfaces, the necessity for careful maintenance generally. Particular emphasis is placed on the part of the fireman.

results.title: Bogota: fragments of a city
results.creator_credit: Jan-henk Kleijn, Manuel Rivos and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: A young photographer walks through the streets of Colombia’s capital, capturing images of life in what he characterises as a sad and old city. His expressive sepia coloured stills of people and his personal impressions and reactions heard in voice-over form the focus of this film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jan-henk Kleijn, Manuel Rivos and International Film Foundation

results.title: Boffins. - Volume 3.
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Film Australia and ABC Video
results.brief_description: Ever wondered why the moon stays up, or why sounds travel through the air? Boffins do. The third volume in this delightful series will entertain children from 4-7 while helping to explain the “Laws of nature.” The episodes are: “Let there be light” (reflecting light), “Feeling blue” (prisms), “Moving matters” (friction), “Miracle of life” (the importance of light, water and soil to sustain life), “The Pledge” (the ability to take charge of scientific experiments and what they really are.)

results.title: Boffins. - Volume 2.
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Film Australia and ABC Video
results.brief_description: Ever wonder why the moon stays up, or why sound travels through air? Boffins do. This second volume of the delightful children’s series will both entertain 4-7 year olds and help explain the “Laws of Nature.” The episodes are: “Upwards and downwards” (the force of gravity), “Life in the balance” (the centre of gravity), “Water water everywhere” (how to use a syphon), “The Disappearing water” (the evaporation of water).
